Traverse the evolutionary history backwards towards more primitive genes. But what you find, which I think is to me quite interesting with respect to what you study is the loss of concordance. So they have this, this large scale pattern memory, whether it be a heart or, you know, liver or whatever, they're working on individual cells disconnect from that, and they can no longer remember that goal. And now they're just amoebas in the environment and they do what they single celled organisms do. And we've developed a kind of integration approach where we don't kill the cells, we don't fix the genetic mutations if they have them. What we do is we reconnect them to the, forcibly reconnect them to the electrical network and they rejoin and they start doing normal things and behaving normally and, you know, and they stop making tumors and that kind of thing. But whereas cancer is that kind of dissociation in space, it now starts to look like aging, like human aging is a dissociation in time, specifically in evolutionary time. And so I think this, this issue of, I mean, you know, I think this is why Alexei brought us together. This issue of dissociation and reassociation and switching is, has profound consequences across scales. You know, not just cognitively, but, but, but somatically and biomedically as well.
